title: The pleasure of poetic pattern - David Silverstein

options.label: B
options.text: The author explains how rhythm and repetition are used in poetry to create a specific effect.

options.label: C
options.text: The author claims that repetition is a bad thing in language.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The repetition of the "th" sound in "So long lives this"

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The repetition of the "i" sound in "So long lives this and this gives life to thee"

options.label: C
options.text: The repetition of the "b" sound in "Betty bought some butter"

options.label: D
options.text: The repetition of the "th" sound in "So long lives this"

options.label: C
options.text: Because repetition and variation can create a specific effect

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a challenge for poets to balance repetition and variation

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Tongue twisters reflect the need for variation in poetic repetition

options.label: D
options.text: Tongue twisters are not related to poetry

options.label: A
options.text: Repetition is only used in poetry to create a specific effect

options.label: B
options.text: Repetition is used in poetry to create a specific effect, but it can also be overused

options.label: C
options.text: Repetition is not used in poetry

options.label: D
options.text: Repetition is only used in music

options.label: A
options.text: We should avoid repetition in language

options.label: B
options.text: We should use repetition in language to create a specific effect

options.label: C
options.text: We all live in a world of wild variation and carry with us our own breath and beat

options.label: D
options.text: Repetition is only used in poetry

title: Can plants talk to each other? - Richard Karban

multiple-choice.question: How do plants primarily communicate with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Through complex sensory or nervous systems

options.label: B
options.text: Through chemical signals in response to their environments

options.label: C
options.text: Through visual cues and body language

options.label: D
options.text: Through auditory signals and sound waves

multiple-choice.question: What are the two primary routes that plant signals take?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the air and through water

options.label: B
options.text: Through the air and through the soil

options.label: C
options.text: Through the soil and through fungi

options.label: D
options.text: Through the air and through direct contact

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for the smell of freshly cut grass?

options.label: A
options.text: Volatile chemicals released by plant leaves

options.label: C
options.text: Plant roots absorbing water and nutrients

multiple-choice.question: What was observed in an experiment where sagebrush leaves were deliberately damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Other branches on the same sagebrush plant got eaten more by insects

options.label: B
options.text: Other branches on the same sagebrush plant got eaten less by insects

multiple-choice.question: Why might a plant warn its neighbors of danger?

options.label: A
options.text: As a deliberate act of altruism

options.label: B
options.text: As an accidental consequence of a self-defense mechanism

multiple-choice.question: How do plants convey warnings to each other?
What determines the effectiveness of communication between plants?

options.label: B
options.text: The similarity of their chemical fingerprints

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of fungi in the soil

multiple-choice.question: What allows plants to communicate with each other through the soil?

options.label: A
options.text: Fungal filaments that form extensive networks

options.label: B
options.text: Plant roots absorbing water and nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: Volatile chemicals released by plant leaves

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a tomato plant responds to blight by activating disease-fighting genes and enzymes?

options.label: A
options.text: Signaling molecules produced by its immune system can travel to a healthy plant and prompt it to turn on its immune system

options.label: B
options.text: The tomato plant becomes more susceptible to disease

options.label: D
options.text: The blight spreads to other plants

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of learning to communicate with plants on their terms?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased resistance to pests and diseases

title: What is abstract expressionism? - Sarah Rosenthal

multiple-choice.question: What art movement is known for eliciting the response "My cat could make that" due to its abstract nature?
When did Abstract Expressionism start?
Which artist is famous for his "existential zips"?
What technique did Jackson Pollock use to create his signature paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: Dripping industrial paint onto a canvas laid on the floor

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of oil and watercolor paints

multiple-choice.question: Who influenced Jackson Pollock's work with their automatic drawings?
What was unique about Pollock's approach to creating his drip paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: He looked for hidden images in the works

options.label: B
options.text: He used a traditional easel to support the canvas

options.label: C
options.text: He controlled the speed and direction of the paint drips

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what makes Pollock's paintings special?

options.label: A
options.text: Anyone can make a similar painting

options.label: B
options.text: They are representations of the mind's hidden contents

options.label: C
options.text: They are physical manifestations of Pollock's psyche

options.label: D
options.text: They are exact replicas of other artists' work

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Pollock and the New York School on the art world?

options.label: A
options.text: They reinforced traditional conventions of painting

options.label: B
options.text: They had no significant influence on art history

options.label: C
options.text: They destroyed conventions of painting that had stood for centuries

options.label: D
options.text: They only created decorative art pieces

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of Pollock's paintings when examined up close?

options.label: B
options.text: They create the illusion of an infinite layered depth

options.label: C
options.text: They display a clear focal point

options.label: D
options.text: They are only visible from a distance

multiple-choice.question: What was an unintended consequence of Pollock's work?

options.label: A
options.text: It made art more accessible to everyone

options.label: B
options.text: It challenged traditional notions of art and creativity

options.label: C
options.text: It reinforced a long-standing elitist aspect of art

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the art world

title: The World's Roundest Object (and Why it Exists)

multiple-choice.question: What is the material used to make the 1kg sphere, and how many atoms does it contain?
Why was the original name "grave" for the base unit of mass changed?

options.label: B
options.text: It sounded too similar to the aristocratic title 'graf'

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the platinum-iridium alloy cylinder that serves as the definition of the kilogram?
Where is the International Prototype Kilogram stored?

options.label: A
options.text: In a climate-controlled vault in New York

options.label: B
options.text: In a climate-controlled vault in Paris

options.label: C
options.text: In a climate-controlled vault in London

options.label: D
options.text: In a climate-controlled vault in Berlin

multiple-choice.question: Why is it a problem that the mass of the platinum-iridium cylinder is not stable over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It affects the definition of the kilogram

options.label: B
options.text: It affects the definition of the meter

options.label: C
options.text: It affects the definition of the second

options.label: D
options.text: It affects the definition of the liter

multiple-choice.question: How many micrograms did the masses of the kilogram replicas diverge by over 40 years?
What is the purpose of creating a silicon sphere in redefining the kilogram?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new physical object to define the kilogram

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the number of atoms in the sphere and redefine Avogadro's constant

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the diameter of the sphere and redefine the meter

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new unit of mass

multiple-choice.question: How is the diameter of the silicon sphere measured?
What is the other approach to redefining the kilogram mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: Fixing Planck's constant using a Watt Balance

multiple-choice.question: How close was the original kilogram to the intended mass of a liter of water at its densest temperature?

title: Why do cats act so weird? - Tony Buffington

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats climb to high vantage points?

options.label: B
options.text: To survey their territory and spot prey

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why domestic cats prefer to chase and pounce on small toys?

options.label: A
options.text: They are bored and need entertainment

options.label: B
options.text: They are trying to assert dominance over their owners

options.label: C
options.text: They are exhibiting an instinctual behavior inherited from their wild ancestors

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to get exercise

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats sharpen their claws on nearby surfaces?

options.label: B
options.text: To relieve stress and condition their claws for climbing and hunting

options.label: C
options.text: To show aggression towards their owners

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats often squeeze into small spaces and hide in unconventional spots?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trying to escape from their owners

options.label: B
options.text: They are exhibiting an instinctual behavior to avoid predators

options.label: C
options.text: They are trying to regulate their body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: They are playing a game of hide-and-seek

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats prefer a clean and odor-free litter box?

options.label: A
options.text: They are fastidious and like cleanliness

options.label: B
options.text: They are trying to avoid attracting predators

options.label: C
options.text: They are trying to assert dominance over their owners

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to conserve water

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible reason why cats purr?

options.label: B
options.text: To heal their muscles and bones

options.label: C
options.text: To show aggression towards other animals

multiple-choice.question: What is the frequency range of a cat's purr that can promote tissue regeneration?
Why do cats often eat small meals throughout the day and night?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trying to conserve energy

options.label: B
options.text: They are exhibiting an instinctual behavior inherited from their wild ancestors

options.label: C
options.text: They are trying to assert dominance over their owners

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to regulate their body temperature

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats often reach into containers and openings?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trying to play with their surroundings

options.label: B
options.text: They are exhibiting an instinctual behavior to hunt for small prey

options.label: C
options.text: They are trying to assert dominance over their owners

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to regulate their body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible way that cats view their human owners?

title: Why is being scared so fun? - Margee Kerr

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, approximately how many people visited a haunted house in the U.S. in October 2015?
What is the primary function of the automatic fight or flight response in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To aid in relaxation and reduce stress

options.label: B
options.text: To prepare the body for danger by releasing chemicals

options.label: C
options.text: To improve critical thinking and problem-solving skills

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce feelings of excitement and happiness

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the high-arousal response experienced during fear and the one experienced during positive states like excitement or happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: The type of chemicals released by the body

options.label: C
options.text: The context in which the response occurs

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people enjoy the sensation of fear in a safe environment, such as a roller coaster or haunted house?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are thrill-seekers who enjoy taking risks

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are able to relabel the experience as enjoyable

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to overcome a phobia

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are seeking a sense of relaxation

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what explains why some people are more prone to thrill-seeking than others?

options.label: B
options.text: Differences in brain chemistry and the threat response

options.label: D
options.text: Differences in age and maturity level

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of doing things that we're afraid of, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us develop a sense of complacency

options.label: B
options.text: It can give us a nice boost of self-esteem

options.label: C
options.text: It can reduce our sense of accomplishment

options.label: D
options.text: It can make us more risk-averse

multiple-choice.question: Why do emotions like fear often bring people together, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they create a sense of competition

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are contagious and can be recreated in others

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are a necessary part of human survival

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are a way to avoid intimacy

multiple-choice.question: What hormone is released during the fight or flight response and aids in feelings of closeness and bonding?
Why do strong emotional experiences like fear tend to be stored in our memory more effectively?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are more relevant to our survival

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more easily forgotten

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one reason why people may enjoy watching horror movies or visiting haunted houses with friends?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows them to confront their fears in a safe environment

options.label: B
options.text: Because it provides a sense of relaxation and calm

options.label: C
options.text: Because it creates a sense of closeness and bonding with others

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a way to avoid social interactions

title: The backwards brain bicycle: un-doing understanding

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the phrase "It's just like riding a bike"?

options.label: A
options.text: It's difficult to learn how to ride a bike.

options.label: B
options.text: It's easy to forget how to ride a bike.

options.label: C
options.text: It's easy and you can't forget how to do it.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Destin when he tried to ride a bike with the handlebars reversed?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to ride it easily.

options.label: B
options.text: He was able to ride it after a few tries.

options.label: C
options.text: He was unable to ride it despite his best efforts.

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't try to ride it.

multiple-choice.question: According to Destin, what is the difference between knowledge and understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: Knowledge is the same as understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: Knowledge is having information, while understanding is being able to apply it.

options.label: C
options.text: Knowledge is being able to apply information, while understanding is having it.

options.label: D
options.text: Knowledge is not necessary for understanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "algorithm" that Destin refers to when talking about riding a bike?

options.label: A
options.text: A set of instructions for building a bike.

options.label: B
options.text: A set of physical forces that interact when riding a bike.

options.label: C
options.text: A set of mental processes that occur when riding a bike.

options.label: D
options.text: A set of rules for riding a bike safely.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Destin take the reversed bike to universities and conferences?

options.label: A
options.text: To show off his riding skills.

options.label: B
options.text: To prove that anyone can ride a reversed bike.

options.label: C
options.text: To demonstrate the difficulty of riding a reversed bike.

options.label: D
options.text: To sell the bike to interested buyers.

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take Destin to learn how to ride the reversed bike?
How long did it take Destin's son to learn how to ride the reversed bike?
What does Destin's experiment demonstrate about children's brains compared to adults' brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Children's brains are less plastic than adults' brains.

options.label: B
options.text: Children's brains are more plastic than adults' brains.

options.label: C
options.text: Children's brains are the same as adults' brains.

options.label: D
options.text: Children's brains are more rigid than adults' brains.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Destin when he tried to ride a normal bike after learning to ride the reversed bike?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to ride it easily.

options.label: B
options.text: He was unable to ride it at first, but eventually was able to.

options.label: C
options.text: He was unable to ride it and never regained the ability.

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't try to ride a normal bike.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main lessons that Destin learned from his experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That knowledge is the same as understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: That knowledge does not equal understanding, and that truth is truth regardless of one's thoughts about it.

options.label: D
options.text: That children's brains are less plastic than adults' brains.

title: The surprising reason you feel awful when you're sick - Marco A. Sotomayor

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of the symptoms experienced when one has the flu?

options.label: B
options.text: The body's immune response to the flu virus

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of the flu virus and a secondary bacterial infection

multiple-choice.question: What type of cells are the first line of attack against an invading pathogen like the flu virus?
What is the role of cytokines in the immune response?

options.label: B
options.text: To recruit and organize more virus-busting cells from the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: To produce antibodies against the invading pathogen

multiple-choice.question: What part of the brain is responsible for controlling temperature, thirst, hunger, and sleep, among other things?
What is the purpose of the rise in body temperature during an infection?

options.label: C
options.text: To slow down bacterial growth and aid the immune system in destroying pathogens

multiple-choice.question: Why does the body reduce thirst during an infection?

options.label: A
options.text: To conserve water for other bodily functions

options.label: B
options.text: To diminish transmission of the infection through sneezes, coughs, vomit, or diarrhea

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of cytokines and prostaglandin on the brain's neurotransmitters?

options.label: A
options.text: They stimulate the release of neurotransmitters

options.label: B
options.text: They have no effect on neurotransmitters

options.label: C
options.text: They disrupt the activity of neurotransmitters, leading to changes in mood and cognitive function

options.label: D
options.text: They increase the production of neurotransmitters

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the immune system treating normal bodily cues as threats?

options.label: A
options.text: The body becomes more resistant to infections

options.label: B
options.text: The body's immune response is weakened

options.label: C
options.text: The body attacks itself, leading to autoimmune diseases

options.label: D
options.text: The body becomes more susceptible to allergies

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the vagus nerve in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit information from the immune system to the brain stem

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate the release of cytokines

options.label: C
options.text: To produce antibodies against the invading pathogen

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall effect of the immune system's response to an infection?

options.label: A
options.text: It always works perfectly to eliminate the infection

options.label: B
options.text: It sometimes works perfectly, but can also lead to autoimmune diseases

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the body's overall health

options.label: D
options.text: It always leads to autoimmune diseases
